abstract.text: Requests permission to save and read the specified HealthKit data types.

legalNotices.copyright: Copyright © 2025 Apple Inc. All rights reserved.

inlineContent.text: The HealthKit store where you’re requesting authorization.
A set containing the data types you want to share.
This set can contain any concrete subclass of the
class (any of the
, or
classes).
If the user grants permission, your app can create and save these data types to the HealthKit store.
An optional set containing the data types you want to read.
This set can contain any concrete subclass of the
class
(any of the
, or
classes ).
If the user grants permission, your app can read these data types from the HealthKit store.
A value used to trigger the request. This value must be a
variable.
Any change to the variable triggers a request.
A block that the system calls after the request is complete. The system passes the result parameter.
HealthKit performs these requests asynchronously when you modify the trigger’s value.
If you call this method with a new data type (a type of data that the user hasn’t previously granted or
denied permission for in this app), the system automatically displays the authorization sheet
when you modify the trigger’s value. The authorization sheet lists all the requested permissions.
After the user finishes responding, HealthKit calls the completion block on a background queue.
If the user has already chosen to grant or prohibit access to all of the types specified,
HealthKit calls the completion when you modify the trigger without prompting the user.
Each data type has two separate permissions, one to read it and one to share it.
You can make a single request, and include all the data types your app needs.

code: fatalError("*** An error occurred while requesting authentication: \(error) ***")
fatalError("*** An error occurred while requesting authentication: \(error) ***")

inlineContent.text: Customize the messages displayed on the permissions sheet by setting the following keys:
customizes the message for reading data.
customizes the message for writing data.
You must set the usage keys, or your app crashes when you request authorization.
Set these keys in the Target Properties list on the app’s Info tab.
After users set the permissions for your app, they can always change them using either the
Settings or the Health app. Your app appears in the Health app’s Sources tab,
even if the user didn’t allow permission to read or share data.

SwiftUI-PageImage-card.png.alt: A black Swift logo on a swirly blue and purple background.

abstract.text: Declare the user interface and behavior for your app on every platform.
A type that represents part of your app’s user interface and provides
modifiers that you use to configure views.
Asynchronously requests permission to read a data type that requires per-object authorization (such as vision prescriptions).
Requests permission to read the specified HealthKit data types.
Requests permission to save and read the specified HealthKit data types.
Presents a preview of the workout contents as a modal sheet
A message to the user that explains why the app requested permission to read samples from the HealthKit store.
A message to the user that explains why the app requested permission to save samples to the HealthKit store.
A type that identifies samples that contain a value from a small set of possible values.
A type that represents data that doesn’t typically change over time.
A type that identifies samples that group multiple subsamples.
An abstract superclass with subclasses that identify a specific type of data for the HealthKit store.
A type that identifies samples that store numerical values.
An abstract superclass for all classes that identify a specific type of sample when working with the HealthKit store.
A type that identifies samples that store information about a workout.
A property wrapper type that can read and write a value managed by SwiftUI.
The access point for all data managed by HealthKit.
An abstract superclass with subclasses that identify a specific type of data for the HealthKit store.
An abstract superclass for all classes that identify a specific type of sample when working with the HealthKit store.
A type that can be compared for value equality.
A value type whose instances are either `true` or `false`.
An unordered collection of unique elements.
The return type of functions that don’t explicitly specify a return type, that is, an empty tuple `()`.
A type representing an error value that can be thrown.
A value that represents either a success or a failure, including an associated value in each case.
